Triggering Event:
He sat alone at his kitchen table, staring at the stack of old family photos as he sipped his morning coffee. The sunlight streaming through the window highlighted the dust motes dancing around the faded Polaroids. His eyes landed on a picture of him and his late wife, taken during their anniversary trip to Paris. They were smiling, arms wrapped around each other, and laughing.

As he gazed at the photo, he couldn't help but think about how many more years they would have spent together if she hadn't passed away. He remembered the argument they had the night before her surgery – he'd been so caught up in his work, and she'd felt like he wasn't there for her. Now, it all seemed so trivial.

The phone rang, shrill in the quiet morning. It was one of his colleagues from the company, asking him to meet with a new project manager. As he listened to the details, a pang of guilt hit him. He was being considered for a leadership role, something his late wife had always wanted for him. A mix of emotions swirled inside him: excitement, nervousness, and regret. What if he'd been able to spend more time with her, support her dreams? The thought sent a wave of remorse washing over him.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: He sighed inwardly as he accepted the meeting invitation. Why did this happen now, when he needed every advantage to succeed? If only he could turn back time, he'd be there for her, make things right. But life didn't work that way. Instead, he was faced with the harsh reality that some things can never be undone. How does this response reflect the cognitive distortion "Should Statements"?

Triggering Event:
He stared blankly at the lines of code on his screen, the cursor blinking tauntingly as he tried to recall why this particular function had worked so well just yesterday. The coffee mug next to him was still warm from breakfast, but the aroma had long since faded, leaving only a faint scent of bitterness.

As he scrolled through the project's issue tracker, his eyes landed on a comment from a team member who had helped him troubleshoot a similar problem months ago. The post was dated two weeks before their last meeting, which had been about wrapping up the project on time. A faint pang of guilt settled in the pit of his stomach as he realized he hadn't responded to the follow-up email since then.

The silence from his colleagues had grown thicker, a palpable reminder that they'd all moved on with their lives while he was stuck in this rut. His phone buzzed with a text from an old friend, inviting him to grab drinks after work – a gesture that felt like a gentle prod into a world he no longer knew how to navigate.

In the background, the hum of the office air conditioning and muffled chatter from coworkers created a sense of detachment, making it hard for him to distinguish between his own thoughts and the din around him. The darkness outside seemed to seep in through the blinds, casting an ominous shadow on the wall behind his chair.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
She stood at the checkout counter, watching as her coworker expertly scanned the last item of the day. The store was closing, and she had managed to sneak in a few minutes of extra time to tidy up before leaving. As she straightened a shelf, her phone buzzed with an incoming text from her partner.

Her heart sank as she read the message - 'Can't wait to see you tonight, love you'. She felt a pang of guilt, knowing she hadn't been able to spend the evening with him as planned. A customer approached the counter, distracting her momentarily, but the feeling lingered.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: She looked at me like I was crazy for even suggesting we have dinner together. "We can't afford it right now," she said bluntly. "And besides, you're always canceling on me." Her words stung, but I knew she was just trying to deflect my suggestion.

Triggering Event:
He stood at his kitchen counter, wiping down the surface for what felt like the hundredth time that day. His mind kept drifting back to the conversation he had with his ex-wife earlier that morning – the one where she mentioned her new boyfriend was coming over for dinner tonight.

As he began prepping for the lunch service, his phone buzzed with an incoming text from his sister. She asked if he needed any help with the afternoon shift, and he hesitated for a moment before responding. He couldn't shake the feeling that his ex might show up unannounced, bringing her new partner along.

His hands moved mechanically as he chopped vegetables, but his eyes kept darting towards the clock. The minutes ticked by slower than usual, and he found himself rehearsing worst-case scenarios in his head – his ex walking into the restaurant, seeing him with customers, and confronting him about their divorce all over again.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: He was just really stressed out about everything right now. His ex-wife's new relationship seemed to be getting more serious every day, and he couldn’t shake off the feeling that it would all come crashing down sooner rather than later. Every little thing felt like a trigger – the way she looked at other men, the conversations they had about kids, even the fact that she had already started dating someone else. It all made him feel so insecure, like he was losing control of his life. It wasn’t just the breakup itself; it was the aftermath too. The constant reminders of what could have been – the empty apartment, the memories still lingering everywhere – it all felt like a weight crushing him. And then there were the texts from her – always pushing boundaries, making him question whether he was good enough for her. It was like no matter how hard he tried, he could never catch up. Every small setback felt like a huge failure. When she cancelled plans last week, he thought it was because she was moving on, but when he saw her with another guy at brunch the next weekend, he realized he was just deluding himself. I guess this is why they say "hurt people hurt people," but sometimes you wish things weren't so complicated. Sometimes you wish things didn't suck so much.

Triggering Event:
He sat alone at his desk, staring at the rejection email from the prestigious publication he had been waiting months to hear back from. The familiar glow of his computer screen seemed to mock him as he scrolled through the generic message – another writer deemed unworthy by the very people who were supposed to be discovering new talent.

As he read the words 'We appreciate your interest, but...' again, his eyes began to itch from the dryness of tears. He rubbed them away, attempting to maintain his professional composure. But it was no use; his gaze drifted to the faint coffee stain on his favorite notebook, a constant reminder of his last article, which had also received a polite rejection.

The phone rang, shrill and unforgiving, breaking the silence. He hesitated before answering, wondering if anyone else would even bother calling him. The voice on the other end was friendly, inquiring about a story idea he had pitched weeks ago. His response came out flat, barely above a whisper, and the conversation ended abruptly as the caller apologized for interrupting and hung up.

In the sudden stillness, his mind wandered to the countless hours spent researching and writing, only to be met with rejection after rejection. A bitter taste lingered in the back of his throat as he forced himself to shut down his laptop and walk away from the disappointment.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: He felt like he was drowning in rejections. Every time he sent an article, he could feel the weight of those emails piling up in his inbox. It wasn't just one or two – it was hundreds, each one a harsh reminder that he was never good enough. Even when he tried to focus on something else, like cooking, he couldn’t shake off the feeling that every recipe he followed was a failure, that every dish he made was a reflection of his own inadequacy. The world seemed to be moving forward without him. People around him had found success, building careers and making names for themselves. They didn’t have to struggle, they didn’t have to keep trying year after year. Meanwhile, he was stuck in this cycle of rejection, unable to break free. The more he worked, the more he realized how much further behind everyone else he really was. Every accomplishment felt hollow, every step forward just a reminder of what he lacked. Even the smallest things – like getting a job or finding love – seemed impossible, like they belonged to someone else entirely. Life was passing him by, and he knew he’d never catch up. It all started with the first rejection. Then there was the second, and third, until it became clear that he was never going to make it. Not in academia, not anywhere. Triggering Event:
She stood at the stove, her eyes fixed on the burnt edges of the soufflé as it slumped towards the counter. Her husband, John, had been watching TV in the living room, oblivious to her frustration. A review from a prominent food critic had appeared online earlier that day, trashing her restaurant's new menu.

The chef's knife slipped from her hand, clattering onto the tile floor as she spun around, her face burning with anger. "John, look at this," she spat, holding up the phone. The critic's scathing words seemed to leap off the screen, echoing in her mind like a cruel mantra. 

For a moment, they locked gazes, his expression softening into concern. But before he could intervene, their daughter walked into the kitchen, her eyes widening at the sight of the fallen knife.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: She was furious when John didn't immediately stop what he was doing to help her clean up the broken knife. Instead, he continued watching TV, seemingly indifferent to her distress. It made sense; after all, shouldn’t he have put everything aside for her? Shouldn't he have rushed to her side, offering support and comfort? But then again, shouldn't she be the one comforting him? After all, hadn't he been distant lately, preoccupied with work? Maybe he wasn't even paying attention to the argument. Why should she assume he was upset about something so trivial? The thought flickered through her mind like a fleeting thought, but the moment passed, and she felt a surge of resentment. Shouldn't he know how much this meant to her? Shouldn't he care more? Shouldn't he understand why she was so upset? In the end, though, she let go of those thoughts, focusing instead on cleaning up the mess and trying to move forward. As she picked up the pieces, a small voice whispered in the back of her head, "Maybe you're overreacting. Maybe he doesn't really care." But she pushed the thought away, telling herself, "You deserve better than someone who wouldn't stand by your side." ---

Triggering Event:
He stood before his latest canvas, paintbrush poised over a vibrant hue. His partner of five years had promised to visit the gallery opening tonight, but as he checked the phone for what felt like the hundredth time, there was no response.

As the sun began to set, casting a warm orange glow through the studio window, he couldn't shake the nagging feeling that something was off. The doorbell rang, but it wasn't until he heard the sound of footsteps outside that he realized his mistake – she hadn't called, she'd forgotten.

A wave of disappointment washed over him as he made his way to the front door, hoping against hope that she might be standing on the other side. But when he opened it, he was met with an empty street and a note scrawled on a piece of paper – 'Sorry, I won't make it. Love you.'<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: He simply couldn’t comprehend how someone he loved could so callously disregard their plans, especially after all they’d shared. It seemed like a cruel joke, one that would leave him heartbroken forever. What kind of person forgets something this important? She must have been in some sort of distress, unable to face whatever awaited her at the gallery. Maybe she was running late due to unexpected traffic or simply lost track of time. Whatever the reason, her lack of communication was a betrayal unlike anything he’d ever experienced. How could she just vanish like this? He felt like he was drowning in a sea of confusion and hurt, unsure of how to process these feelings. Every moment since receiving the note had felt like an eternity, each second ticking away like grains of sand in an hourglass. As he stared blankly into space, memories of their relationship flooded his mind – laughter, tears, whispers, and promises. They were supposed to celebrate this new chapter together, not drift apart in silence. What if she thought this through carefully, trying to avoid hurting him, but ultimately finding herself unable to confront reality? Perhaps she was overwhelmed by her own fears, unsure of how to handle the pressure of being in the spotlight. Or maybe she was simply tired, needing some alone time to recharge. Either way, her absence left him shattered, wondering if their love could withstand such indifference. He couldn’t help but wonder if this was more than just a simple oversight, if maybe deep down she was trying

Triggering Event:
He stood at the stove, his hands moving with precision as he chopped vegetables for tonight's dinner. His wife had asked him to pick up something special from the market today, but when he got home, she was nowhere to be found. A text message from her phone lay on the counter, a vague apology and a request for him to meet her at the wine bar downtown.

As he cooked, his mind wandered to their conversation earlier – about how she'd been stressed lately with work and needed some time to herself. He couldn't help but feel like he was being left behind again, that she didn't see the effort he put into making their life together run smoothly.

The sizzle of onions on the stovetop snapped him back to attention, but his focus remained elsewhere. The door swung open and his wife walked in, her eyes red-rimmed from crying. She handed him a bottle of expensive wine without a word, and turned to leave.

"Where have you been?" he asked, trying to keep his tone neutral, but his voice came out sharper than he intended. The silence that followed was oppressive, and for a moment, they just stared at each other, the tension between them palpable.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: He seemed distant, his usual warmth replaced by a cold indifference. It was like he hadn’t even noticed me standing there, staring at him through tears. I felt like an outsider looking in, like I wasn’t part of this scene anymore. He kept talking about how I’d left him hanging, but it was hard to hear anything else over the sound of my own emotions crashing down around me. When I finally spoke, he looked away, his expression shutting off completely. I could tell he was still upset, but now it felt like I was the problem. We both knew we were supposed to talk about what happened, but all I wanted was to get out of here before things escalated further. His words cut deep, leaving me feeling raw and exposed. Even though I knew he was right, I couldn’t shake the feeling that I was losing myself in our relationship. One minute we’re laughing together, and the next, I’m facing anger and disappointment. It’s exhausting, and I wonder if we can ever find balance again.

Triggering Event:
She stood at the staff room table, sipping her lukewarm tea as colleagues bustled around her. The school's annual parent-teacher conference was about to begin, and she felt a familiar knot in her stomach. As she reviewed the notes on her tablet, her eyes landed on the comments section of one particularly difficult parent's file.

"Underwhelming experience for my child," the comment read, followed by a scathing review of her teaching methods. A wave of self-doubt washed over her, and for a moment, she forgot she had spent years honing her craft. Her mind replayed the conversation with the parent, her attempts to address their concerns, and the way they'd dismissed her efforts.

As the door swung open, signaling the start of the conference, she hastily gathered her papers and fled to the staff room's empty corner, her hands shaking slightly as she tried to calm herself down. The hum of the coffee machine seemed to grow louder, and she felt a bead of sweat trickle down her spine. She took another sip of tea, trying to distract herself from the nagging voice in her head that kept echoing the parent's harsh words.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
He stood at the front of his classroom, surveying the rowdy assembly of students as he tried to regain their attention. The lesson plan had gone off without a hitch until one student had accidentally knocked over his water glass during morning roll call. Now, as he began to hand out papers, the kid snickered and mouthed "spill" to his friends.

The class erupted into laughter, and the teacher's face grew hot with embarrassment. He tried to power through, but it seemed like every time he turned around, someone was making a joke about his clumsiness. Even his usually stoic colleague, Mrs. Johnson, couldn't help but stifle a grin when she walked by the classroom door.

As the day went on, the teasing continued – whispered comments in the hallways, snickers during meetings, and even a sarcastic comment from the principal during his office hours. It wasn't until he got home, where his wife greeted him with a sympathetic smile and a lukewarm cup of coffee, that he realized just how humiliated he must have looked all day.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: He probably exaggerated the situation, and it wasn’t that bad. Maybe if I didn’t focus so much on the incident, things would’ve been different.
